reviewText: A swashbuckler with pirates, smugglers and patriots, this is marvelous entertainment, with two actors who are riveting to watch, and some history, which though embellished in some places and condensed in others, is in essence correct.Jean Lafitte was flamboyant and a favorite of the ladies, and with his horde of sea robbers had his headquarters on an island in Barataria Bay, and controlled the waterways known as the bayou. As Lord Byron wrote of Lafitte,"He left a Corsair's name to other times-Linked with one virtue and a thousand crimes".Yul Brynner is terrific as Lafitte, with swagger and strut, and even singing a beautiful Creole ballad, which Lafitte was known to do. The Costume Design in this film received an Oscar nomination, and should have won for the way they managed to fit Brynner's numerous outfits.In the smaller but pivotal part of Andrew Jackson, Charlton Heston is downright magnificent and looks fabulous. With thick white hair, his resemblance to General Jackson is a marvel. Both Brynner and Heston, who two years earlier had starred in C.B. DeMille's "The Ten Commandments", have command and presence that fills the screen and is a joy to watch.Others in the cast are Charles Boyer, charming and humorous as Brynner's friend and fellow pirate, Inger Stevens as Brynner's love interest and the daughter of Governor Clairborne (E.G. Marshall), and Claire Bloom as tough girl Bonnie Brown. The score by Elmer Bernstein is wonderful, and cinematography by Loyal Griggs very good, especially the scene of the British advancing, with bagpipes and drums, in the Battle of New Orleans, which took place in the Winter of 1814-15. The Red Coats falling to Jackson's troops was accurate, as the British lost an astounding 2,600 to the loss of only 13 of Jackson's men.A remake of Cecil B. DeMIlle's 1938 film, this was supervised by him, and directed by actor Anthony Quinn. DeMille also gives us a small history lesson at the start of the film, with maps to demonstrate where the action takes place.Total running time is 121 minutes.

reviewText: Very few films are made about the War of 1812, but the 1958 version of 'The Buccaneer' delivers a compelling story! Yul Brynner portrays the swashbuckler Jean Lafitte who longs to have a country to belong to. Who else but Charlton Heston could portray General Andrew Jackson? While this tale may not be completely historically correct, it engulfs the viewer in a tale of love, courage, and honor. No one should be disappointed watching one of the most underrated films. I highly recommend this film!The DVD itself offers no special features. However, the quality of film/disc is worthy of anyone's collection.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The film itself with all it's flaws, including being the first and only attempt at 'directing' for Anthony Quinn (...then, DeMille's son-in-law, taking over for a very ill Cecil B. DeMille who'd suffered several strokes)..is still a classic.  The performances are good, considering the 'DeMille-stiffness' that is always a trademark...even in "The Ten Commandments"  But looking beyond that, it's still fun.  Definitely not a 'history-lesson' as much as it is a classic American 'mythology'.  The same group who brought you DeMille's famous epic just 2 years before are here, including Elmer Bernstein giving an overblown but beautiful score similar to the one for Moses and Ramesses.  Yul Brynner is a suave and 'muscular' Jean Laffete and Heston does a great job as Andrew Jackson considering the script.  Claire Bloom, Charles Boyer, and a beautiful Inger Stevens all make this a 'classic' swashbuckler'...somewhat.

reviewText: I saw this movie three or four times when it first came out on the big screen. It might be considered a little sugary today, but compared to the poor releases we now see from Tinseltown, it is miles ahead.The United States in the War of 1812 were not the losers nor the "bad guys." There were several reasons for the war, most of them based on the British understanding that these states were still colonies and therefore liable for assisting their naval war against the French (e.g., by the impressment of American seamen). The outcome of the war forever abolished that idea; for that reason, the War of 1812 is justly termed America's Second War for Independence and a key victory. It is true that the British did not wear kilts at new Orleans, but this movie, as well as the 1938 version, if anything downplay the stupendous achievement by Jackson and the civilians, militia and few career soldiers on the American side. A small British force did advance on the opposite side of the river, but their initial landings were soundly thrashed, their preceding artillery barrage was smashed and their naval attack upriver was decisively repulsed, all before the great attack of January 8th (a national holiday for Americans up to the Civil War). The victory also meant that the British were barred from seizing and holding the city as a naval base, which the treaty of Ghent, signed in December, 1814, was deliberately worded to let them do (see Peter Reilly's British at the Gates).This movie is enjoyable and, at times, inspiring and, guess what - it is also factual.

reviewText: Yul Brynner buckles his swash with the best of them, and this is a great story.  Just how historically accurate it is can be debated, but there is no argument as to the entertainment value.  Charlton Heston joins Brynner  in a tremendous cast that includes a young Lorne Greene and other fine  character actors.  The Buccaneer takes place during the most over-looked  conflict in American filmmaking; the War of 1812.  It provides an  interesting glimpse at just how odd, and how untrustworthy, political and  military bedfellows can be.

reviewText: If you are Jean Lafitte (Yul Brynner), you're the boss of the privateers based south of New Orleans on an isle in the waters of Barataria Bay;  following the bayous north, affords you easy access to the lucrative market of New Orleans's society, to sell the booty plundered from Spanish ships sailing the Gulf of Mexico and the Caribbean Sea.  You have an iron rule that your captains must follow and that is to never touch American ships, and as long as your corsairs comply, shoppers from New Orleans are more than happy to look the other way so that they can buy valuables for next-to-nothing, with the added benefit that there is no duty to be paid.Of course, the government of the new state of Louisiana takes a dim view of privateers operating off their coast and are particularly upset about the loss of potential tax revenues.  Governor Claiborne has placed a reward on your head and the navy is making plans against Barataria. . . .If you are the British, your task of taking New Orleans would be made much easier if you could make use of Barataria's backdoor access to New Orleans, but first you have to win over these pirates.  Pardons for Lafitte's men, commissions in the King's navy, and a hoard of gold should do the trick;  you make the offer. . . .Charged with the defense of New Orleans, General Andrew Jackson (Charlton Heston) and his small ragtag force of regulars, buckskinned sharpshooters, and others make ready as best they can;  they are woefully short on gunflints and powder, short on combatants, and short on time.  The fate of New Orleans rests on the decision of one man: Jean Lafitte. . . .Picture (DVD - 2012): 3.5 to 4.  Measured Aspect Ratio: 1.77:1.  Subtitles: none.  Special Features: none.

reviewText: Just checked this Blu Ray out and it was a distinct pleasure. All the historical notes say DeMille was too ill to shoot this movie but I dare say the final product still bears his stamp. The Technicolor and Vista Vision images are eye popping and Yul Brynner is far more charismatic than Frederic March was in DeMilles's 1938 version. Besides it is worth the purchase alone for Charlton Heston's commanding turn as Andrew Jackson. The score by Elmer Bernstein is sweeping and majestic. Historically it might be inaccurate but this is a first class movie treaure. It is meant to be treasured for what it is, a first class entertainment.

reviewText: This is for the Olive Blu-ray. This is a remake of the 1938 Cecil B. DeMille movie that starred Frederic March. Viewers will argue over which version was better, but both are wonderful IF you like C. B. DeMille movies. They both have all the best, and worst, of his "showmanship".I have the black & white 1938 movie on an Olive DVD, and the 1958 remake on their Blu-ray. Both are surprisingly good. Anthony Quinn was in the '38 as an actor and he directs the '58. It is the only movie he ever directed. Yul Brynner is good as Jean Lafitte. The plot is very similar in both movies with only the survivor of a pirate raid changing from a Dutch maid in the original to a boy, and Lafitte's love interest becomes the Governor's daughter in the remake. As Inger Stevens plays the daughter, this is a nice change. A good, beautiful actress who died way too young.The Olive Blu-ray is well done in widescreen and color and is almost the same price as the DVD. It is worth the price.

reviewText: As a history buff, reenactor and illustrator, I tend to watch movies like this without too much expectation. Hollywood is not known for getting the historical facts straight. The costumes and uniforms were horrible and the casting was a joke. Now, I'll admit, Heston wasn't bad as Andy "By God" Jackson. He actually bore more than a little ressemblance to "Old Hickory", but at times the dialog he spouted was cartoonish and silly. Yul Brynner (I hope I spelled that correctly) was only fair as Lafitte but he came across as rather wooden at times. Hardly an inspiring leader of a pirate empire. Of course as elusive as the real Lafitte is to historians, we'll probably never get a useful perspective of the man. Like so many Hollywood productions, historical fact is ignored. This is especially noticeable in the battle scenes where kilted Highlanders march blindly into volley after volley of musketry and endless cannon fire only to be mowed down by keen eyed "dirty shirts". HOGWASH! Maybe one day a director with a sense of history will re-make this one and get the facts straight. But Antonio Banderas or Johnny Depp would probably be cast as Lafitte. GAAAAGGGGG!!!!!

reviewText: This is one of the few War of 1812 films you will find out there. Despite the fact that this is now the 200th anniversary of the conflict.  Why is this so? Americans don't like being the bad guys or the losers, and we were a bit of both in this war. This movie is your standard Hollywood late swashbuckler adventure,  a C.Demille remake of an earlier film by the same name of thee same subject.  The time was running out on these old classics when this one was made. Still, Brenner and Heston are really good. Heston catches the mad side of old Hickery well and show what were his inspirational qualities as well.As for Laffete, we don't know that much about him. He has been the subject of myth and romance for many years and this film largely adds to those legends. Lafette played no active role in the New Orleans battle, and while his gunners were likely talented they were not the battle winners this film shows. In fact, there is no reason why we won this battle accept the British made several key mistakes, and were reackless and in their actions.  Jackson was a competent general, but his role in the victory, and our need to feel good about one episode of this otherwise embarrassing conflict has been overrated.Provoked by Britain's desire to prevent free trade with Napolean and his land locked European empire, the US wanted to play a double game of trading with both sides.  The young nation soon found out that you can't play both sides in a world wide conflict between two rival empires. In truth Britain was arrogant in its dealings with US shipping, and outright pressganging of US sailors for the hard pressed Royal Navy did not help matters.  But US designs on Indian lands and British North America were obvious and the War Hawks thought the whole thing would be merely a matter of marching northwards.The United States was eager to flex its muscile and make good on invading British North America, as the last time in 1775 had been another set-back. After two years of incompetence, during which out of frustration the town of York (present day Toronto) was burned along with several other communities, the US had little to show for its sorry effort by early 1814.With the conclusion of the Napoleanic Wars, the British decided to send 16,000 veterans of Wellington's campaigns in Spain over to punish the United States. This was truly a crisis as the United States had such troops to counter these remarkable troops.  With the US fleet blocked up or destroyed after some heroic actions, the whole of the East Coast was open to British incursion. A roving squadron landed troops and avenged the burning of York by sacking Washington in late 1814. New Orleans was next on the list and its capture would have severed Louisanna and likely changed the whole course of US growth in the 19th Century.Maj-Gen Edward Packenham commanded a most impressive force to accomplish this mission. There was little Jackson could do to stop 8,000 British veterans, but the terrain and over-confidence would prove their undoing. The highlight of the movie for me is the British attack of the 93rd Highlanders. This is highly stylized, but the atmosphere portrayed in the film with murky sets is effective.  the British rocket battery scene is very interesting.  These were the same rocket types that inspired our current National Anthem that we deal with today. A better tune might have been "Hail Columbia!"The 93rd are here shown in kilts and blue facings on the cuffs which is incorrect They wore trews (paints)instead. It is also unlikely that they had a massed pipe band like this as well.  Scottish pipers and drummers were only just beginning to combine their music resources in this period.  Still, the scene where the regiment is given the command to attack "Will battalion advance in line of attack, quick march!" is very impressive.  The 93rd's attack was typical of the bungled affair this battle was for the British. Ordered to attack after their initial columns were repulsed, the 93rd could have overtaken the American line, but were halted and re-directed when Packenham fell mortally wounded and the whole British command and control fell apart. The 93rd Highlanders, now known as the Argyll and Sutherland Highlanders, or 5th battalion The Royal Regiment of Scotland lost nearly 2/3rds of their strength in this lop-sided American victory.Oddly enough, when the British attack was called off, the forces on the other side of the Mississippi had completely overwhelmed the American defenders there. This success, had it been better coordinated might have changed the course of the battle. Unfortunately, the extent of Packenham's setback on the other side of the river prevented any British success in this area. The film does a workmanship job of depicting some of these events, though the role played by the pirates is indeed over-played. Still, a worthy classic and about the only thing you ever see on this conflict in the movies. Nice to see it on DVD again.

reviewText: I saw this film around the same time as Disney's Great Locomotive Chase and was enthralled for the same reason; an action flick with period uniforms/costumes, cool weapons and not too blood thirsty. Growing older I eventually picked it up on VHS and still love the film. Heston's Jackson virtually jumps out of a history book at you. i still remember the line he gave to a new recruit complaining of being humgry: "Son, you aren't hungry until you can wipe your face with the slack of your belly!" LOL!! Brenner plays, well...Brynner (as he did in Taras Bulba, The Magnificent Seven and even Westworld). One difference here - he plays Brynner with "hair" on his head. Charles Boyier plays a forgettable role as a former Napoleonic officer who has fallen on hard times and waundered into Lafitte's gang of pirates. Lorne Green (funny because he was a Canadian and Canada was on the other side in this war) plays one of the more undesirable New Orleans politician types at odds with Jackson.  The female actors are beautiful...that's all one can say.The film is kind of cornball, but does a fair job of showing the dire straits the American Army was in at that time during the war of 1812. Predictible pirate scenes and inter-personal rivalry which descends into cliche. Similar to the travis and Bowie characters in John Wayne's version of the Alamo. Love scenes would make a teeneager sob ("I love you so much I have to leave and never see you again" type of stuff. LOL!!).So why the 5 stars? Because it is a forgotten gem of latter 1950s epic films, one of the few, if not the only, film on the Battle of New Orleans, the short battle scene is both suspenseful ansd spectacular (the fog, pipes/drums, red coats, battlefield rockets...all of it). Also, if you just suspend reality and go along for the ride, its a great film. Perhaps I like it so much because I was nine when I first saw it and still see it through those eyes. I sincerely believe that you, too, would like this film if you take the leap and look at it as just an adventure film. Classic stuff - produced by Cecil DeMille and directed by Anthony Quinn (but feels more like a Disney production of the period - which is meant as a compliment).
summary: A favorite when I was a kid

reviewText: I used to love these types of big, bold, colorful costume epics as a kid and I still like them today.  It's been a number of years since I've seen The Buccaneer but it was always one of my favorites.  Directed by Anthony Quinn the film stars Charlton Heston as General Andrew Jackson and Yul Brynner as pirate Jean LaFitte and is sent against the backdrop of the war of 1812.  Lafitte and his pirates control a local and strategically placed Island near New Orleans.  While he refrains from attacking American vessels he's still not in the good graces of Jackson.  Jackson is faced with a dire dilemma...the British are massing a large force and planning to attack New Orleans and the American forces are vastly outnumbered.  They turn to ally with LaFitte.  Lafitte's men want them to side with England as they think they will certainly win, but LaFitte gets assurances from Jackson that his men will be pardoned if they aid the Americans.  This deal is complicated when one of the Pirates under LaFittes command attacks an American ship and kills everyone except a boy who escapes.  Even though LaFitte new nothing about the attack he accepts responsibility.This is a truly lavish epic with great costumes, epic battles and dramatic performances by the entire cast.  Some might argue that Heston and Brynner tend to ham it up a bit but I think this is more of a product of their era when bold, over-the-top performances like this were the norm and subtlety was not in the equation.  The battles are staged quite well with lots of action.  The fine supporting cast includes Charles Boyer, E.G. Marshall, and Lorne Greene.  Quite well done and I hope we will see a DVD release soon.  It's too good to be only on VHS and out of print.
